overview: How to appeal against a decision about a rent increase, changes to a lease or a decision about a council house, park home or caravan
title: Housing tribunals

table.body:
You can appeal to a Rent Assessment Committee if you're a private tenant and think your rent is too high.

The committee is independent, and can change the rent if it's unfair.

You can usually appeal when you get a letter from your landlord about a rent increase.

%The committee can raise, lower or agree with the amount of rent you're challenging.%

##Time limits for appealing to the committee

There are deadlines for appealing to the committee, depending on the type of tenancy:

- assured or assured shorthold tenancy: before the new rent is due to start
- regulated tenancy: within 28 days of the rent being decided by the rent officer

^If you're not sure what type of tenancy you have, check your tenancy agreement, or use [Shelter’s tenancy checker.](http://england.shelter.org.uk/get_advice/downloads_and_tools/tenancy_checker/ "Shelter's tenancy checker"){:rel="external"}^

##Appeal to the committee

To appeal to the committee, fill in the application form for your type of tenancy:

$D [Download assured shorthold tenancy (DOC 369KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/global/forms/tribunals/residential-property/rac2-assured-shorthold-tenancy.doc "Assured shorthold tenancy (DOC 369KB)"){:rel="external"}$D
$D [Download assured periodic tenancy (DOC 328KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/global/forms/tribunals/residential-property/rac1-assured-tenancy-agricultural-occupancy.doc "Assured tenancy (DOC 328KB)"){:rel="external"} $D
$D [Download statutory periodic tenancy (DOC 379KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/global/forms/tribunals/residential-property/rac3-statutory-periodic-tenancy.doc "Statutory periodic tenancy (DOC 379KB)"){:rel="external"}$D

Send the form to your [local rent assessment panel.](http://www.justice.gov.uk/global/contacts/hmcts/tribunals/residential-property.htm "local rent assessment panel"){:rel="external"}

##Regulated tenancies

If you have a regulated or 'protected' tenancy, write to the Valuation Office Agency:

$C **Valuation Office Agency**  
Wycliffe House  
Green Lane  
Durham  
DH1 3UW $C

They will look at your case and forward it to the rent assessment panel in your area.

##Get help and advice

You can get help and advice from Shelter or the Residential Property Tribunal Service:

$C **Shelter**  
0808 800 4444 $C

$C **Residential Property Tribunal Service**  
0845 600 3178 $C

##How the committee makes its decision

The committee may ask for:

- more information - eg what you think the rent should be and why
- permission to inspect the property

You may have to go to a hearing, with your landlord, to tell the committee why you think the rent is too high.

If you and your landlord agree, the committee can decide on the case without a hearing, using written evidence.

##The committee's decision

The committee will send its decision in writing, saying:

- what the rent should be
- the date the rent is payable from
- the reasons for their decision

##If you disagree with the committee's decision

The only way to challenge the committee’s decision is through the High Court.

If you wish to do this, you may want to [get legal advice.](http://legaladviserfinder.justice.gov.uk/AdviserSearch.do "get legal advice"){:rel="external"}

%You have to appeal to the High Court within 28 days of getting the full reasons for the committee's decision.%
table.title: Rent Assessment Committee: disputes about rent

table.body:
If you're a leaseholder, you can appeal to the Leasehold Valuation Tribunal if you disagree with changes to your lease, including:

- service charges
- extending a lease
- buying the freehold
- insuring the building

The tribunal is independent, and can decide if a charge is too high or unreasonable, or if changes to the lease are fair.

##Appeal to the tribunal

To apply to the tribunal, fill in an [application form.](http://www.justice.gov.uk/global/forms/hmcts/tribunals/residential-property/index.htm "application form"){:rel="external"}

The forms are listed under the heading ‘leasehold disputes’.

Send the form to your [local rent assessment panel.](http://www.justice.gov.uk/global/contacts/hmcts/tribunals/residential-property.htm "local rent assessment panel"){:rel="external"}

##Cost of appealing to the tribunal

You may have to pay a fee if:

- you're appealing against a service or administration charge
- the case goes to a hearing

**Service or administration charge - amount in dispute** | **Tribunal fee**
- | -
£500 or less | £50
£500 to £1,000 | £70
£1,000 to £5,000 | £100
£5,000 to £15,000 | £200
£15,000 or more | £350

Taking the case to a hearing costs £150.

You can pay by postal order or cheque (payable to 'HM Courts & Tribunals Service').

##Help paying costs

If you're on benefits, like Income Support, you can ask for help with your fees, using the form below:

$D [Download 'application to Leasehold Valuation Tribunal for a reduction or waiver of fees' (DOC, 266KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/global/forms/tribunals/residential-property/lvt1-reduction-waiver-fees.doc "Download 'application to Leasehold Valuation Tribunal for a reduction or waiver of fees' (DOC, 266KB)"){:rel="external"} $D

##Get help and advice

You can get help and advice from the Leasehold Advisory Service or the Residential Property Tribunal Service:

$C **Leasehold Advisory Service**  
0845 600 3178  
[Online enquiry form](https://clients.lease-advice.org/Default.aspx "online enquiry form"){:rel="external"} $C

$C **Residential Property Tribunal Service**  
0845 600 3178 $C

##What happens after you send your appeal

The tribunal may ask for:

- more information - eg a copy of the lease
- permission to inspect the property

You may have to go to a hearing with the freeholder.

If there isn't a hearing, the tribunal will ask you to send written evidence.

The tribunal will send you a letter giving its decision (usually within 6 weeks of any hearing).

##If you disagree with the tribunal's decision

You may be able to appeal against the decision to a higher tribunal, called the Upper Tribunal (Lands Chamber).

To do this, you have to ask the Leasehold Valuation Tribunal for permission to appeal, using the form below:

$D [Download 'application for permission to appeal to an upper tribunal' (DOC, 123KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/global/forms/tribunals/residential-property/lvt-permission.doc "Download 'application for permission to appeal to an upper tribunal' (DOC, 123KB)"){:rel="external"} $D

%You must send this form to your local rent assessment panel within 21 days of getting its decision.%

Find out more about appealing to the [Upper Tribunal (Lands Chamber).](http://www.justice.gov.uk/guidance/courts-and-tribunals/tribunals/lands/index.htm "Upper Tribunals (Lands Chamber)"){:rel="external"}
table.title: Leasehold Valuation Tribunal: changes to your lease

table.body:
The Residential Property Tribunal can help solve disagreements about:

- council homes
- park homes (static caravans or mobile homes)

##Council homes

You can appeal to the tribunal if you disagree with a decision about your council home, eg to:

- reuse an empty building
- improve parts of a building
- demolish or close a building
- make a property safe
- restrict how many people live in a property

You can also appeal if you're refused the 'Right to Buy' your council or housing association home because it's suitable for elderly people.

##Park homes

You can appeal to the tribunal if you disagree with a decision about your park home - eg to:

- change or end a residence agreement
- change the pitch fee
- move a park home
- repair a park home
- transfer a park home to someone else

##Appealing to the tribunal

To make an appeal to the tribunal, you have to fill in an [application form.](http://www.justice.gov.uk/global/forms/hmcts/tribunals/residential-property/index.htm "park homes"){:rel="external"}

The forms are listed under the headings:

- 'Housing Act appeals and applications'
- ‘Right to Buy appeals’
- ‘Park homes’

Send the form to your [local rent assessment panel.](http://www.justice.gov.uk/global/contacts/hmcts/tribunals/residential-property.htm "local rent assessment panel"){:rel="external"}

##Cost of appealing to the tribunal

You may have to pay a £150 fee for some cases. The application form will tell you if you have to pay a fee.

You can pay by postal order or cheque (made payable to 'HM Courts & Tribunals Service').

##Help paying costs

If you're on benefits, like Income Support, you can ask for help with your fees, using the form below:

$D [Download 'application to Residential Property Tribunal for a reduction or waiver of fees' (DOC, 266KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/global/forms/tribunals/residential-property/rpt2-waiver-fees.doc "Download 'application to Residential Property Tribunal for a reduction or waiver of fees' (DOC, 266KB)"){:rel="external"} $D

##Get help and advice

You can get help and advice from your local Citizens Advice Bureau or the Residential Property Tribunal Service:

$C **Citizens Advice**  
0844 411 1444 (England)  
0844 477 2020 (Wales)  
[Citizens Advice website](http://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/index/getadvice.htm "Citizens Advice website"){:rel="external"}
$C

$C **Residential Property Tribunal Service**  
0845 600 3178 $C

##What happens after you send your appeal

The tribunal may ask you for permission to inspect the property or park home.

You may have to go to a hearing with the council or site owner.

If there isn't a hearing, the tribunal will ask you to send written evidence.

The tribunal will send you a letter giving its decision, usually shortly after any hearing.

##If you disagree with the tribunal's decision

You may be able to appeal against the decision to a higher tribunal, called the Upper Tribunal (Lands Chamber).

To do this, you have to ask the Residential Property Tribunal for permission to appeal, using the form below:

$D [Download 'application for permission to appeal to an upper tribunal' (DOC, 123KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/global/forms/tribunals/residential-property/rpt-permission-jun-11.doc "Download 'application for permission to appeal to an upper tribunal'(DOC, 123KB)"){:rel="external"} $D

%You must send this form to your local rent assessment panel within 21 days of getting its decision.%

Find out more about appealing to the [Upper Tribunal (Lands Chamber).](http://www.justice.gov.uk/guidance/courts-and-tribunals/tribunals/lands/index.htm "Upper Tribunals (Lands Chamber)"){:rel="external"}
